htmlEmbed:
Remote Work Is Costing Manhattan More Than $12 Billion a Year6/27/2024

That translates into big savings for individuals, who are spending nearly $5,000 a year less on meals, shopping and entertainment near work as schedules shift to a new norm.

Bloomberg, work from home, remote work, empty offices, Manhattan, hybrid work, work schedule, business district, transit, Midtown, retail sales, economy, eric adams, small business, housing market, real estateRead

                link.type = 'text/css';
                link.rel = 'stylesheet';
                link.href = cssPath;

                document.head.appendChild(link);
            }

                script.async = 'async';
                script.src = scriptPath;

                if (crossOrigin) script.crossOrigin = crossOrigin;

                document.body.appendChild(script);

    <meta name="description" content="Manhattans economy relies on restaurants, retailers and other businesses. What happens when commuters work from home and offices are partially empty?" />

    <meta property="og:title" content="Remote Work Is Costing Manhattan More Than $12 Billion a Year" />
    <meta property="og:description" content="That translates into big savings for individuals, who are spending nearly $5,000 a year less on meals, shopping and entertainment near work as schedules shift to a new norm." />
    <meta property="og:image" content="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/i__FQapTBO0Q/v0/-1x-1.jpg" />

data-testid="gifting"><div class="dvz-v0-gift-article" data-headline="Remote Work Costs NYC $12 Billion a Year By Killing Big Offices																							" style="--button-background-color:#ffffff;--button-color:#000000"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="with--index-1 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base css--section-break ds-mx-4"><p>New York City is bustling with office workers again, at least on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays. Its a different mood on Fridays and Mondays, when subway cars empty out, Sweetgreen salad lines thin and, come happy hour, there are plenty of seats at the bar. The in-person workweek has shrunk to three days.</p></div><div class="with--index-2 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Three years into the pandemic, business leaders and city officials around the world are still trying just about everything to lure employees back into offices and revive local economies. But new data on in-person work analyzed by Bloomberg News show that in a number of cities across the US, Fridays at the office are dead. Mondays are a crapshoot. And returning to pre-pandemic work schedules looks like a lost cause. </p></div><section class="css--social-embed ds-my-8 ds-py-2 ds-mx-auto ds-max-w-11/12 md:ds-max-w-lg ds-text-xxs ds-font-sans"><div class="css--social-embed-inner ds-text-center"><iframe src="https://omny.fm/shows/the-big-take/the-real-price-of-work-from-home/embed?style=Cover" width="100%" height="180" allow="autoplay; clipboard-write" frameborder="0" title="The Real Price of Work From Home"></iframe></div></section><div class="with--index-3 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Nowhere is the economic cost of remote work more pronounced when it comes to spending than in the worlds leading financial center: New York. Manhattan workers are spending at least $12.4 billion less a year due to about 30% fewer days in the office, according to a Bloomberg News analysis using exclusive <a href="https://wfhresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/WFHResearch_updates_February2023.pdf" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">data</a> from Stanford University economist Nicholas Blooms WFH Research group.  That figure was calculated by multiplying the annual inflation-adjusted loss in spending per worker by the US Census Bureaus estimated nearly 2.7 million commuters and residents who worked in Manhattan in 2019.</p></div><div class="with--index-4 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>That means the average worker is spending $4,661 less per year on meals, shopping and entertainment near their offices in New York. That compares to $3,040 in San Francisco and $2,387 in Chicago. These behaviors are most entrenched in cities with longer commutes, a higher proportion of white-collar workforces and longer-lasting pandemic restrictions.</p></div><div class="ds-relative ds-my-6 ds-mx-auto ds-block lg:ds-my-10 ds-min-h-ad css--ad"><aside class="dvz-v0-ad css--ad-unit" data-position="immersive-4" data-testid="_t_ad_" data-ad-sizes-mobile="300x250" data-ad-sizes-tablet="300x250" data-ad-sizes-desktop="728x90"></aside></div><div class="with--index-5 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Losing $12.4 billion a year translates into missed sales for restaurants, retailers and other businesses that drive New Yorks economic engine. Office vacancies pose a multibillion-dollar crisis for Americas biggest office real estate market. The transit systems finances are in free fall. Chief executives like Goldman Sachs Group Inc.s David Solomon and JPMorgan Chase & Co.s Jamie Dimon are growing impatient with workers. And the fiscal threat to tax revenue verges on the existential: What is the value of a city when workers dont need to be there anymore? </p></div><div class="with--index-6 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>If less income tax is being paid in New York City, said Comptroller Brad Lander, then its hard to figure out how to capture enough value to maintain the subways and invest in the schools and keep the city safe and clean and all the things that really matter.</p></div><div class="with--index-7 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>How New York fares is instructive for other financial centers around the world: Only 6% of Londoners previously able to work from home said their employers expect them to be in the office five days a week, according to a <a href="https://content.tfl.gov.uk/travel-in-london-report-15.pdf" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">report</a> from the mayors office. And last year, about 14% of jobs posted in all of Tokyos 23 wards were mostly remote, compared with 3% in 2019, according to job site Indeed.</p></div><div class="css--default-width-wrapper ds-w-11/12 ds-text-current"><h2 class="css--chapter ds-font-sans ds-font-bold ds-leading-6 ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base">Spending Shift</h2></div></div><div class="with--index-8 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>When a citys commuting base disappears, sales and transit revenue fall, the commercial property tax base shrinks and labor income shrinks for people who provide goods and services to those workers, Steven Davis, senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, a conservative think tank, said in a recent panel.</p></div><div class="with--index-9 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Across the US, spending has grown from 2019, according to Mastercard SpendingPulse, which measures in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment. But disparities between the days of the week are evident in New York: Overall US spending in October 2022 rose by an average 23% on Fridays, compared with 20% in the Greater New York area and just 11% in Manhattan. The numbers dont account for inflation.</p></div><div class="with--index-10 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Less spending by workers in the central areas means a lot less sales tax revenue, said Jose Maria Barrero, a professor at Mexicos Instituto Tecnologico Autonomo and researcher with the WFH group who calculated the figures for Bloomberg. If you have fewer commuters, that means less revenue.</p></div><div class="ds-relative ds-my-6 ds-mx-auto ds-block lg:ds-my-10 ds-min-h-ad css--ad"><aside class="dvz-v0-ad css--ad-unit" data-position="immersive-5" data-testid="_t_ad_" data-ad-sizes-mobile="300x250" data-ad-sizes-tablet="300x250" data-ad-sizes-desktop="728x90"></aside></div><div class="with--index-11 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>These shifts are most visible in Manhattans Financial District and Midtown, where trading desks and cubicles lay bare at the start and end of the week. Many restaurants and retailers have closed up shop and foot traffic and subway riders have plummeted. </p></div><div class="with--index-12 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Bankers, lawyers and other executives who expense black car rides to their New York City offices have also rejiggered their commuting schedules to focus on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, according to data from HQ Corporate Mobility, which works with Fortune 500 companies to book, bill and expense cars.</p></div><div class="with--index-13 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>From June to December 2022, rides taken on Mondays and Fridays reached only around 33% and 38% of pre-pandemic levels, respectively, according to HQ data of about 400,000 rides over the last three years. On Thursdays, that rises to roughly 43%.</p></div><div class="bbg-photo-viewer css--photo-viewer-wrapper ds-cursor-pointer ds-relative ds-m-0 ds-p-0 md:ds-w-derived with--index-0 ds-w-derived ds-self-auto ds-justify-self-auto" style="--derived-width:100%"><div class="photo-viewer-source css--photo-viewer-source ds-m-0 ds-p-0 ds-transition-opacity ds-opacity-100 ds-duration-100" ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">Nate Diaz, who works in the Financial District, saves $100 a week by working from home. <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-italic">Photographer: Ismail Ferdous/Bloomberg</span></div></figcaption></div></figure></div></div></div><div class="with--index-14 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>On Fridays, I definitely want to be in the comfort of my own home, said Nate Diaz, 24, who goes into the financial firm S&P Global on Tuesdays, when he knows his coworkers will be there.</p></div><div class="with--index-15 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>At the office, he heads to lunch with colleagues  spending up to $20 on Chipotle or Chopt  and happy hours on Stone Street.</p></div><div class="with--index-16 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Diaz saves $100 a week by working from home, though hell sometimes grab coffee in his Astoria, Queens, neighborhood. He used the extra cash to buy new bulletin boards and a massage chair for his souped-up home office.</p></div><div class="with--index-17 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>People have changed their lifestyle and their behavior, said Michelle Meyer, North America chief economist at Mastercard Economics Institute. If you are working from home that day, youre not commuting into your office, and going to the bodega next to your office.</p></div><span><div class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><figure class="ds-block ds-font-sans ds-text-base css--toaster-wrapper ds-w-full ds-overflow-hidden ds-relative ds-max-w-full ds-h-auto ds-p-0"><h4 class="css--toaster-title ds-my-0 ds-font-bold ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-0">Manhattan Spending Growth Lags That of US</h4><p class="css--toaster-subtitle ds-text-xms md:ds-text-xs lg:ds-text-sm ds-leading-tight ds-mt-0.5">How much average weekday sales grew from October 2019 to October 2022</p><noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iHG3q4rShvYA/v0/pidjEfPlU1QWZop3vfGKsrX.ke8XuWirGYh1PKgEw44kE/-1x-1.png" alt="Chart" class="ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full" of US" scrolling="no" loading="lazy" id="MueA-JOGkf" height="300" class="css--toaster-iframe ds-w-full ds-outline-none ds-border-0 ds-my-2 ds-mx-0" role="application"></iframe><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">Note: Data track in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-block ds-mt-2">Source: Mastercard SpendingPulse</span></div></figcaption></div></figure></div></span><div class="with--index-18 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>The growth has turned the neighborhoods where hybrid workers live into a new kind of business district. Foot traffic in New Yorks four other boroughs recovered by 85% or more by the end of 2022 compared with pre-pandemic levels, according to data from Orbital Insight. Manhattan's recovery rate lags at 78%.</p></div><div class="with--index-19 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Its more pronounced among restaurants and bars, where transactions increased by 48% in Brooklyn in the fourth quarter of 2022 from 2019, compared with 18% in Manhattan, according to data tracked by commerce company Square. The two boroughs were growing at the same rate pre-pandemic, according to Square Research Lead Ara Kharazian.</p></div><div class="css--default-width-wrapper ds-w-11/12 ds-max-w-11/12 css--multi-image-outer-wrapper ds-mx-auto ds-my-4"><div class="css--multi-image-inner-wrapper multi_image_layout_format_2 ds-relative ds-flex ds-w-full ds-items-start ds-flex-wrap ds-items-start ds-justify-center"><div class="bbg-photo-viewer css--photo-viewer-wrapper ds-cursor-pointer ds-relative ds-m-0 ds-p-0 md:ds-w-derived with--index-0 ds-w-full ds-self-end ds-justify-self-auto" style="--derived-width:50%"><div class="photo-viewer-source css--photo-viewer-source ds-m-0 ds-p-0 ds-transition-opacity ds-opacity-100 ds-duration-100" style="cursor:zoom-in"><figure class="css--multi-image-figure ds-block ds-h-auto ds-m-2 with--index-0 ds-m-2 md:ds-m-2"><div class="css--multi-image-wrapper ds-transition-all"><noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iZV1n.TOLxlU/v0/640x-1.jpg" alt="Customers at the Fitzpatrick Hotel Group bar in New York. lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-ml-0 sm:ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">The Fitzpatrick Hotel Group, which runs the Wheeltapper Pub at 141 East 44th Street, is trying to find unique ways to drum up business while the usual after-work crowd stays home. <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-italic">Photographer: Ismail Ferdous/Bloomberg</span></div></figcaption></div></div></div><div class="with--index-20 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Average retail spending on Mondays in October rose by 28% in the Bronx, 21% in Queens and 18% in Brooklyn, compared with just 2% in Manhattan from the same period in 2019, according to Mastercard data.</p></div><div class="with--index-21 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Outer-borough growth could be a silver lining for New York, but a recently published <a href="https://edc.nyc/sites/default/files/2022-12/New-NY-Action-Plan-Making_New_York_Work_for_Everyone.pdf" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">plan</a> to revive the city focuses less on the newly vibrant areas and more on inching back to a Manhattan-centric economy.</p></div><div class="with--index-22 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>While Mayor Eric Adams now requires government employees to work in-person five days a week, hes had less luck pushing business leaders to mandate stricter in-office requirements. </p></div><div class="with--index-23 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Its time, he said last year. New York City cant run from home.</p></div><span><div class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><figure class="ds-block ds-font-sans ds-text-base css--toaster-wrapper ds-w-full ds-overflow-hidden ds-relative ds-max-w-full ds-h-auto ds-p-0"><h4 class="css--toaster-title ds-my-0 ds-font-bold ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-0">New Yorkers Returned to Office in 2022, Except Fridays</h4><p class="css--toaster-subtitle ds-text-xms md:ds-text-xs lg:ds-text-sm ds-leading-tight ds-mt-0.5">Share of employees badging into NYC metro offices each weekday</p><noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iIxtBekRcEmk/v0/pidjEfPlU1QWZop3vfGKsrX.ke8XuWirGYh1PKgEw44kE/-1x-1.png" alt="Chart" class="ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full" loading="lazy"/></noscript><iframe src="https://www.bloomberg.com/toaster/v2/charts/50b271de68a54af29672bb5e8e69bc38?hideLogo=true&hideTitles=true&web=true&" title="New Yorkers Returned to Office in 2022, Except Fridays" scrolling="no" loading="lazy" id="1tf--79zMZ" height="300" class="css--toaster-iframe ds-w-full ds-outline-none ds-border-0 ds-my-2 ds-mx-0" role="application"></iframe><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">Note: Data cover the New York City metro area <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-block ds-mt-2">Source: Kastle Systems</span></div></figcaption></div></figure></div></span><div class="ds-relative ds-my-6 ds-mx-auto ds-block lg:ds-my-10 ds-min-h-ad css--ad"><aside class="dvz-v0-ad css--ad-unit" data-position="immersive-6" data-testid="_t_ad_" data-ad-sizes-mobile="300x250" data-ad-sizes-tablet="300x250" data-ad-sizes-desktop="728x90"></aside></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><div data-testid="_chapter_" class="css--chapter-wrapper ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-text-current"><h2 class="css--chapter ds-font-sans ds-font-bold ds-leading-6 ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base">Existential Risk</h2></div></div><div class="with--index-24 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Worker attendance at New York offices during the fourth quarter of 2022 recovered to about 43% of pre-pandemic levels on average, according to badge-tracking data from Kastle Systems. On Tuesdays, though, that jumps to an average 51% and plunges to 23% on Fridays.  </p></div><div class="with--index-25 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Office attendance has ticked up when employers issue mandates for more in-person days, but theyre not a cure-all and a wide variability in company policies has left many pandemic-era habits in place. For example, Blackstone asked investment professionals to come into the office five days a week,  but workday traffic at its headquarters at 345 Park Avenue remains half of its 2019 level. At American Express, which <a href="https://about.americanexpress.com/newsroom/press-releases/news-details/2022/American-Express-Officially-Launches-Amex-Flex-Our-New-Way-of-Working/default.aspx" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">doesnt</a> have in-office requirements, only 31% of pre-pandemic workday traffic is back at its headquarters at 200 Vesey Street.</p></div><div class="with--index-26 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>At eight major Manhattan office buildings, foot traffic is down about 52% on Fridays and 45% on Mondays compared with pre-Covid, according to a Bloomberg News analysis of Placer.ai data. </p></div><span><div class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><figure class="ds-block ds-font-sans ds-text-base css--toaster-wrapper ds-w-full ds-overflow-hidden ds-relative ds-max-w-full ds-h-auto ds-p-0"><h4 class="css--toaster-title ds-my-0 ds-font-bold ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-0">Manhattan Offices Are Filling Back Up  Just Not Every Day
</h4><p class="css--toaster-subtitle ds-text-xms md:ds-text-xs lg:ds-text-sm ds-leading-tight ds-mt-0.5">Eight big office buildings are filling up again but Fridays are quiet</p><noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iRqP9.2J7qvE/v0/pidjEfPlU1QWZop3vfGKsrX.ke8XuWirGYh1PKgEw44kE/-1x-1.png" alt="Chart" class="ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full" loading="lazy"/></noscript><iframe src="https://www.bloomberg.com/toaster/v2/charts/351283062a314e2ca9a4418f462ae19e?hideLogo=true&hideTitles=true&web=true&" title="Manhattan Offices Are Filling Back Up  Just Not Every Day
" scrolling="no" loading="lazy" id="5nN_LfOLzt" height="300" class="css--toaster-iframe ds-w-full ds-outline-none ds-border-0 ds-my-2 ds-mx-0" role="application"></iframe><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">Note: Foot traffic data cover tenants and retail spaces within geofenced boundaries. Recovery rates represent 2022 foot traffic volumes as a percentage of comparable 2019 levels. <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-block ds-mt-2">Source: Bloomberg News analysis of Placer.ai data</span></div></figcaption></div></figure></div></span><div class="with--index-27 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Researchers have <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4124698" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">modeled</a> a 40% drop in office market value as office towers sit partially empty, which they estimate would cost $5 billion in lost tax revenue, or 5% of the citys annual budget. New Yorks future sales tax revenue could also diminish as half-empty office buildings drive sluggish spending. It could also take a hit to its income tax base if employees continue to relocate elsewhere. </p></div><div class="with--index-28 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Thats a big hole that will need to be plugged with new taxes, lower spending, said Columbia University professor Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh, who referred to the situation in a recent panel as a potential urban doom loop.</p></div><div class="css--default-width-wrapper ds-w-11/12 ds-max-w-11/12 css--multi-image-outer-wrapper ds-mx-auto ds-my-4"><div class="css--multi-image-inner-wrapper multi_image_layout_format_5 ds-relative ds-flex ds-w-full ds-items-start ds-flex-wrap ds-items-start ds-justify-center"><div class="bbg-photo-viewer css--photo-viewer-wrapper ds-cursor-pointer ds-relative ds-m-0 ds-p-0 md:ds-w-derived with--index-0 ds-w-full ds-self-auto ds-justify-self-auto" style="--derived-width:33.33333333333333%"><div class="photo-viewer-source css--photo-viewer-source ds-m-0 ds-p-0 ds-transition-opacity ds-opacity-100 ds-duration-100" style="cursor:zoom-in"><figure class="css--multi-image-figure ds-block ds-h-auto ds-m-2 with--index-0 ds-m-2 md:ds-m-2"><div class="css--multi-image-wrapper ds-transition-all"><noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/ikrWcvoMBus0/v0/640x-1.jpg" alt="A crowd of commuters at the Wall Street subway station in New York. lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-ml-0 sm:ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">The city is still seeing the impacts of hybrid work on its transit system, where Mondays and Fridays see a decrease in ridership. <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-italic">Photographer: Ismail Ferdous/Bloomberg</span></div></figcaption></div></div></div><div class="with--index-29 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>The city is still seeing the impacts on its transit system, where weekday ridership has recovered only 64% on average in January and revenue shortfalls are expected to hit over $2 billion a year through 2026.</p></div><div class="with--index-30 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>With pandemic aid running out, the agency is <a data-terminal="NSN RN5GMTDWX2PT" data-terminal-type="STORY" data-terminal-value="RN5GMTDWX2PT" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-19/new-york-city-subway-faces-weekday-cuts-in-service-ehile-boosting-weekend-trains" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="New York City Subway Faces Weekday Cuts in Service Ehile Boosting Weekend Trains">planning</a> service cuts to about seven lines on Mondays and Fridays, including the 1 train that connects Manhattan and the Bronx, and the L and F trains, which run across Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan. </p></div><div class="with--index-31 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>The change will be felt by working-class New Yorkers, who are back to work five or six days a week. They cant afford a $50 Uber, and arent able to work remotely, said MTA Chief Executive Officer Janno Lieber in November.</p></div><span><div class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><figure class="ds-block ds-font-sans ds-text-base css--toaster-wrapper ds-w-full ds-overflow-hidden ds-relative ds-max-w-full ds-h-auto ds-p-0"><h4 class="css--toaster-title ds-my-0 ds-font-bold ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-0">NYC Subway Ridership Is Down 70% From Pre-Pandemic Levels</h4><p class="css--toaster-subtitle ds-text-xms md:ds-text-xs lg:ds-text-sm ds-leading-tight ds-mt-0.5">Average weekday subway station entries in 2019 and 2022</p><noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/inciUsrA7XS8/v0/-1x-1.png" alt="Chart" class="ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full" loading="lazy"/></noscript><iframe src="https://www.bloomberg.com/toaster/v2/charts/a9b59eda36284ebdb9184f0e1a163708?hideLogo=true&hideTitles=true&web=true&" title="NYC Subway Ridership Is Down 70% From Pre-Pandemic Levels" scrolling="no" loading="lazy" id="_7S-hdd-Qc" height="300" class="css--toaster-iframe ds-w-full ds-outline-none ds-border-0 ds-my-2 ds-mx-0" role="application"></iframe><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">Note: Data for both years cover 10 weeks between September and December, excluding holidays. Entry data for the Wall Street station  is for the Wall Street/William Street location serving the 2 and 3 lines. <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-block ds-mt-2">Source: Metropolitan Transportation Authority</span></div></figcaption></div></figure></div></span><div class="ds-relative ds-my-6 ds-mx-auto ds-block lg:ds-my-10 ds-min-h-ad css--ad"><aside class="dvz-v0-ad css--ad-unit" data-position="immersive-7" data-testid="_t_ad_" data-ad-sizes-mobile="300x250" data-ad-sizes-tablet="300x250" data-ad-sizes-desktop="728x90"></aside></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both"><div data-testid="_chapter_" class="css--chapter-wrapper ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-text-current"><h2 class="css--chapter ds-font-sans ds-font-bold ds-leading-6 ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base">Forget about it</h2></div></div><div class="with--index-32 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>While New York has a history of overcoming economic shocks like the September 11 terrorist attacks and the 2008 financial crisis, business owners say they are struggling to adapt to the new three-day workweek. </p></div><div class="with--index-33 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Sams Falafel owner Emad Ahmed said foot traffic near Wall Street is the worst it's been in his 30 years of business. Only on a sunny midweek day do sales recover to about 60% of what they were, he said. Meanwhile, the rising cost of gas and ingredients have pressured his business.</p></div><div class="with--index-34 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Monday, Friday, forget about it, said Ahmed, 57, who parks his truck in Zuccotti Park and notches only 30% of his pre-Covid revenue on those days. You lose money when nobody is here. </p></div><div class="bbg-photo-viewer css--photo-viewer-wrapper ds-cursor-pointer ds-relative ds-m-0 ds-p-0 md:ds-w-derived with--index-0 ds-w-derived ds-self-auto ds-justify-self-auto" style="--derived-width:100%"><div class="photo-viewer-source css--photo-viewer-source ds-m-0 ds-p-0 ds-transition-opacity ds-opacity-100 ds-duration-100" style="cursor:zoom-in"><div class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--photo-viewer-wrapper-inner"><figure class="css--image-figure ds-mx-0 ds-my-auto ds-block ds-relative ds-w-full ds-h-auto" data-testid="_t_figure_"><div class="css--image-wrapper ds-w-full ds-relative ds-h-auto"><noscript><img className="css--image" loading="lazy" style="margin: 0 auto; width: 100%" src=https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/640x-1.jpg /></noscript><img src="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/640x-1.jpg" data-testid="_t_image_" data-srcset="https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/220x-1.jpg 220w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/480x-1.jpg 480w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/640x-1.jpg 640w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/720x-1.jpg 720w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/960x-1.jpg 960w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/1020x-1.jpg 1020w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/1200x-1.jpg 1200w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/1280x-1.jpg 1280w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/1400x-1.jpg 1400w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/1800x-1.jpg 1800w, https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iy0f2CgHBmhk/v0/2000x-1.jpg 2000w, " data-sizes="auto" alt="Sams Falafel " loading="lazy" class="css--image lazyload ds-p-0 ds-h-auto ds-object-center landscape:ds-p-0 landscape:ds-object-center" draggable="true"/></div><div class="css--caption-outer-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-ml-0 sm:ds-mx-auto"><figcaption class="css--caption-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-xl ds-pr-2 ds-font-sans ds-mt-1" data-testid="_caption_credit_"><div class="css--caption ds-leading-tight ds-text-xms ds-mt-1 ds-mr-2">Sams Falafel owner Emad Ahmed said foot traffic near Wall Street is the worst it's been in his 30 years of business. <span class="css--credit ds-text-xxs ds-italic">Photographer: Ismail Ferdous/Bloomberg</span></div></figcaption></div></figure></div></div></div><div class="with--index-35 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Jordan Cohen, the manager of Bryant Park Grill in Midtown Manhattan, said about 40% fewer diners are now showing up on Mondays and Fridays for the power lunch hubs $22 chicken Caesar salad and $50 braised lamb shank.</p></div><div class="with--index-36 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>To make up for the lost business, the restaurant has leaned on corporate events on slow weeknights and has clawed back around 90% of pre-pandemic revenue. But even those events get dinged by the hybrid workweek: At parties where employers invite 300 attendees, only about half will show up, Cohen said. </p></div><div class="with--index-37 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>And Sweetgreen, a salad chain ubiquitous with New York Citys fleece-vest set, said the start and end of the week used to be its strongest sales days, but Mondays and Fridays are definitely not the same, said Sweetgreen co-founder and CEO Jonathan Neman, on a November earnings call. </p></div><div class="with--index-38 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>On a Monday in October at a Bryant Park Sweetgreen known for lines stretching down the block on busy days, office workers in button-down shirts and high heels breezed in and out with $15 salads in hand.</p></div><div class="with--index-39 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>That was surprisingly easy, a woman leaving the salad counter said to her companion. </p></div><div class="with--index-40 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Yeah, it doesnt feel like a madhouse in there, which is weird, he replied. </p></div><div class="with--index-41 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Bloomberg found the longest wait for a salad at the Bryant Park Sweetgreen at noon was around 13.5 minutes on a Wednesday. By contrast, it took only four minutes to breeze through the line on a Friday.</p></div><div class="ds-relative ds-my-6 ds-mx-auto ds-block lg:ds-my-10 ds-min-h-ad css--ad"><aside class="dvz-v0-ad css--ad-unit" data-position="immersive-8" data-testid="_t_ad_" data-ad-sizes-mobile="300x250" data-ad-sizes-tablet="300x250" data-ad-sizes-desktop="728x90"></aside></div><div class="with--index-42 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Sweetgreen is now renegotiating leases with landlords to structure rent as a percentage of sales, versus a fixed amount common with commercial rents.</p></div><div class="with--index-43 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>With offices emptier on Mondays and Fridays, business travelers are cutting hotel stays short by a day or two and flying in just for midweek, said Vijay Dandapani, president and CEO of the Hotel Association of New York City.</p></div><div class="with--index-44 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Business travel has rebounded the most in places like Austin, Texas, and Charlotte, North Carolina, where workers are back in physical offices, according to hospitality data and analytics firm STR. In Austin, hotels recovered to 92% of pre-pandemic occupancy on Mondays of last year, while New York hotels were only around 83% recovered, and San Francisco was even further behind, at 74%. </p></div><div class="with--index-45 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>Resistance to coming into the office at the end of the week runs so deep that when a large financial company rented out a Fitzpatrick Hotel Group bar in Midtown Manhattan on a Friday evening, only about a third of the 130 invited employees showed up, said John Fitzpatrick, who owns the company's two New York City hotels.</p></div><div class="with--index-46 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>To lose that amount of business on a Friday, which is one of your busiest days, is huge, said Fitzpatrick, who depends on business travelers for 70% of his clientele.</p></div><div class="with--index-47 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>To drum up business, hes considering raffling a free trip to Ireland to Friday bar customers. Another marketing idea is to encourage tourists to extend their New York City holidays by promoting the hotel as a remote-work haven on Fridays.</p></div><div class="with--index-48 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p>We have to come up with something, Fitzpatrick said.</p></div><div class="with--index-49 theme--default css--paragraph-wrapper children:ds-max-w-screen-sm children:ds-mx-auto children:ds-leading-normal ds-font-serif ds-text-xs md:ds-text-sm lg:ds-text-base ds-mx-4"><p><em>With <a data-terminal="BIO 22806669" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="22806669">Alexander Cohen</a>, <a data-terminal="BIO 23006119" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="23006119">Christian Richey</a> and <a data-terminal="BIO 20216875" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="20216875">Natalie Wong</a></em></p></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">Edited by <a data-terminal="BIO 19471188" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="19471188">Shelly Banjo</a>, <a data-terminal="BIO 22332791" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="22332791">Danielle Balbi</a> and <a data-terminal="BIO 17268083" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="17268083">Chloe Whiteaker</a><br/>Photo Editing by <a data-terminal="BIO 19812614" data-terminal-type="PEOPLE" data-terminal-value="19812614">Marie Monteleone</a> <br/>Lead Photograph by Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg</span></p></div></div><span class=""><div class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--decoration"><hr class="ds-border-t ds-border-current ds-mt-1"/></div></span><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">Methodology: </span></p></div></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">The calculated cost of remote work in Manhattan incorporates an inflation-adjusted loss of $4,661 per person per year in New York City, which the WFH Research group calculated from their 2020 Survey of Working Arrangements and Attitudes (SWAA) of workers' estimated weekly spending on their meals, shopping, and entertainment near the workplace in 2019. The calculated loss in spending provided exclusively to Bloomberg News accounted for a roughly  30% reduction for in-person days at the office. The $4,661 per person per year reduction was then multiplied by the nearly 2.7 million estimated number of commuters and residents who worked in Manhattan in 2019. The estimated number of workers used in the calculation is based on data from the 2019 American Community Survey compiled by the US Census Bureau.</span></p></div></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">Mastercard SpendingPulse data track the growth of both in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment in specific geographies. The data are not adjusted for inflation and exclude spending on automobiles. Mastercard SpendingPulse defines the New York City area as the wider designated marketing area (DMA) in its calculations.</span></p></div></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">Bloomberg News's analysis of Placer.ai data is based on activity within geofenced boundaries at eight major Manhattan office buildings. Data capture cellphone signals that stay for longer than 150 minutes within those boundaries to reflect worker and business foot traffic. The geolocation data reflect activities   for the entirety of each building, including all the tenants, as well as any retail or public space within each boundary. Recovery rates are calculated as 2022s full-year weekday traffic volumes for each building as a percentage of the comparable 2019 records.</span></p></div></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">In the analysis of New York MTA ridership data, two subway stations' gate-level entry data were analyzed for a 10-week period between September and December, excluding holidays,  for 2019 and 2022 respectively.</span></p></div></div><div style="margin:0 auto" class="css--column-width-wrapper ds-max-w-screen-sm ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-full ds-relative ds-my-4 ds-mx-auto ds-clear-both css--footer-wrapper"><div class="ds-list-none ds-font-sans ds-opacity-60 ds-text-current css--footer ds-block ds-text-xxs ds-mt-0 ds-mb-2"><p><span class="css--footer is--footer">The Kastle Systems badge data cover office buildings in the New York metro area that use the company's service during the period of analysis. Recovery rates are calculated using a baseline period prior to the pandemic.<br/></span></p></div></div><div class="ds-relative ds-my-6 ds-mx-auto ds-block lg:ds-my-10 ds-min-h-ad css--ad"><aside class="dvz-v0-ad css--ad-unit" data-position="immersive-9" data-testid="_t_ad_" data-ad-sizes-mobile="300x250" data-ad-sizes-tablet="300x250" data-ad-sizes-desktop="728x90"></aside></div><span><section class="css--recirc-wrapper ds-w-11/12 lg:ds-w-10/12 ds-h-auto ds-text-current ds-transition-opacity ds-max-w-5xl ds-m-auto ds-font-sans"><h2 class="css--recirc-title ds-text-base ds-font-normal ds-border-b ds-border-current">More On Bloomberg</h2><div class="css--recirc-list ds-flex ds-flex-wrap lg:ds-flex-nowrap ds-flex-row ds-justify-between" style="min-height:200px"><aside class="css--recirc-item ds-text-current ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full ds-h-auto ds-transition-transform lg:ds-w-1/4 lg:ds-my-2 lg:ds-mx-2"></aside><aside class="css--recirc-item ds-text-current ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full ds-h-auto ds-transition-transform lg:ds-w-1/4 lg:ds-my-2 lg:ds-mx-2"></aside><aside class="css--recirc-item ds-text-current ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full ds-h-auto ds-transition-transform lg:ds-w-1/4 lg:ds-my-2 lg:ds-mx-2"></aside><aside class="css--recirc-item ds-text-current ds-my-0 ds-mx-auto ds-w-full ds-h-auto ds-transition-transform lg:ds-w-1/4 lg:ds-my-2 lg:ds-mx-2"></aside></div></section></span></section></div></main>

The calculated loss in spending provided exclusively to Bloomberg News accounted for a roughly  30% reduction for in-person days at the office. The $4,661 per person per year reduction was then multiplied by the nearly 2.7 million estimated number of commuters and residents who worked in Manhattan in 2019. The estimated number of workers used in the calculation is based on data from the 2019 American Community Survey compiled by the US Census Bureau.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"entityRanges\":[],\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"FOOTER\",\"length\":808,\"offset\":0}]}],\"entityMap\":{}},\"html\":\"\\u003Cp\\u003E\\u003Cspan class=\\\"css--footer is--footer\\\"\\u003EThe calculated cost of remote work in Manhattan incorporates an inflation-adjusted loss of $4,661 per person per year in New York City, which the WFH Research group calculated from their 2020 Survey of Working Arrangements and Attitudes (SWAA) of workers' estimated weekly spending on their meals, shopping, and entertainment near the workplace in 2019. The calculated loss in spending provided exclusively to Bloomberg News accounted for a roughly  30% reduction for in-person days at the office. The $4,661 per person per year reduction was then multiplied by the nearly 2.7 million estimated number of commuters and residents who worked in Manhattan in 2019. The estimated number of workers used in the calculation is based on data from the 2019 American Community Survey compiled by the US Census Bureau.\\u003C\\u002Fspan\\u003E\\u003C\\u002Fp\\u003E\"},\"index\":52,\"footnote\":false,\"sectionBreak\":false,\"hideFromTerminal\":false,\"hideFromAppleNews\":false}},{\"id\":\"qX_8Z4QE-x\",\"type\":\"Paragraph\",\"props\":{\"cid\":\"qX_8Z4QE-x\",\"text\":{\"raw\":{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"7fv31\",\"data\":{\"cid\":\"wC6s57wT7z\",\"footnote\":false,\"sectionBreak\":false,\"hideFromTerminal\":false,\"hideFromAppleNews\":false},\"text\":\"Mastercard SpendingPulse data track the growth of both in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment in specific geographies. The data are not adjusted for inflation and exclude spending on automobiles. Mastercard SpendingPulse defines the New York City area as the wider designated marketing area (DMA) in its calculations.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"entityRanges\":[],\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"FOOTER\",\"length\":339,\"offset\":0}]}],\"entityMap\":{}},\"html\":\"\\u003Cp\\u003E\\u003Cspan class=\\\"css--footer is--footer\\\"\\u003EMastercard SpendingPulse data track the growth of both in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment in specific geographies. The geolocation data reflect activities   for the entirety of each building, including all the tenants, as well as any retail or public space within each boundary. readabilityObject.title: Remote Work Costs NYC $12 Billion a Year By Killing Big Offices
readabilityObject.content:
Remote Work Is Costing Manhattan More Than $12 Billion a Year

February 12, 2023, 7:00 PM UTC

New York City is bustling with office workers again, at least on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays. Its a different mood on Fridays and Mondays, when subway cars empty out, Sweetgreen salad lines thin and, come happy hour, there are plenty of seats at the bar. The in-person workweek has shrunk to three days.

Three years into the pandemic, business leaders and city officials around the world are still trying just about everything to lure employees back into offices and revive local economies. But new data on in-person work analyzed by Bloomberg News show that in a number of cities across the US, Fridays at the office are dead. Mondays are a crapshoot. And returning to pre-pandemic work schedules looks like a lost cause.

Nowhere is the economic cost of remote work more pronounced when it comes to spending than in the worlds leading financial center: New York. Manhattan workers are spending at least $12.4 billion less a year due to about 30% fewer days in the office, according to a Bloomberg News analysis using exclusive data from Stanford University economist Nicholas Blooms WFH Research group. That figure was calculated by multiplying the annual inflation-adjusted loss in spending per worker by the US Census Bureaus estimated nearly 2.7 million commuters and residents who worked in Manhattan in 2019.

That means the average worker is spending $4,661 less per year on meals, shopping and entertainment near their offices in New York. That compares to $3,040 in San Francisco and $2,387 in Chicago. These behaviors are most entrenched in cities with longer commutes, a higher proportion of white-collar workforces and longer-lasting pandemic restrictions.

Losing $12.4 billion a year translates into missed sales for restaurants, retailers and other businesses that drive New Yorks economic engine. Office vacancies pose a multibillion-dollar crisis for Americas biggest office real estate market. The transit systems finances are in free fall. Chief executives like Goldman Sachs Group Inc.s David Solomon and JPMorgan Chase & Co.s Jamie Dimon are growing impatient with workers. And the fiscal threat to tax revenue verges on the existential: What is the value of a city when workers dont need to be there anymore?

If less income tax is being paid in New York City, said Comptroller Brad Lander, then its hard to figure out how to capture enough value to maintain the subways and invest in the schools and keep the city safe and clean and all the things that really matter.

How New York fares is instructive for other financial centers around the world: Only 6% of Londoners previously able to work from home said their employers expect them to be in the office five days a week, according to a report from the mayors office. And last year, about 14% of jobs posted in all of Tokyos 23 wards were mostly remote, compared with 3% in 2019, according to job site Indeed.

Spending Shift

When a citys commuting base disappears, sales and transit revenue fall, the commercial property tax base shrinks and labor income shrinks for people who provide goods and services to those workers, Steven Davis, senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, a conservative think tank, said in a recent panel.

Across the US, spending has grown from 2019, according to Mastercard SpendingPulse, which measures in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment. But disparities between the days of the week are evident in New York: Overall US spending in October 2022 rose by an average 23% on Fridays, compared with 20% in the Greater New York area and just 11% in Manhattan. The numbers dont account for inflation.

Less spending by workers in the central areas means a lot less sales tax revenue, said Jose Maria Barrero, a professor at Mexicos Instituto Tecnologico Autonomo and researcher with the WFH group who calculated the figures for Bloomberg. If you have fewer commuters, that means less revenue.

These shifts are most visible in Manhattans Financial District and Midtown, where trading desks and cubicles lay bare at the start and end of the week. Many restaurants and retailers have closed up shop and foot traffic and subway riders have plummeted.

Bankers, lawyers and other executives who expense black car rides to their New York City offices have also rejiggered their commuting schedules to focus on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, according to data from HQ Corporate Mobility, which works with Fortune 500 companies to book, bill and expense cars.

From June to December 2022, rides taken on Mondays and Fridays reached only around 33% and 38% of pre-pandemic levels, respectively, according to HQ data of about 400,000 rides over the last three years. On Thursdays, that rises to roughly 43%.

On Fridays, I definitely want to be in the comfort of my own home, said Nate Diaz, 24, who goes into the financial firm S&P Global on Tuesdays, when he knows his coworkers will be there.

At the office, he heads to lunch with colleagues spending up to $20 on Chipotle or Chopt and happy hours on Stone Street.

Diaz saves $100 a week by working from home, though hell sometimes grab coffee in his Astoria, Queens, neighborhood. He used the extra cash to buy new bulletin boards and a massage chair for his souped-up home office.

People have changed their lifestyle and their behavior, said Michelle Meyer, North America chief economist at Mastercard Economics Institute. If you are working from home that day, youre not commuting into your office, and going to the bodega next to your office.

The growth has turned the neighborhoods where hybrid workers live into a new kind of business district. Foot traffic in New Yorks four other boroughs recovered by 85% or more by the end of 2022 compared with pre-pandemic levels, according to data from Orbital Insight. Manhattan's recovery rate lags at 78%.

Its more pronounced among restaurants and bars, where transactions increased by 48% in Brooklyn in the fourth quarter of 2022 from 2019, compared with 18% in Manhattan, according to data tracked by commerce company Square. The two boroughs were growing at the same rate pre-pandemic, according to Square Research Lead Ara Kharazian.

Average retail spending on Mondays in October rose by 28% in the Bronx, 21% in Queens and 18% in Brooklyn, compared with just 2% in Manhattan from the same period in 2019, according to Mastercard data.

Outer-borough growth could be a silver lining for New York, but a recently published plan to revive the city focuses less on the newly vibrant areas and more on inching back to a Manhattan-centric economy.

While Mayor Eric Adams now requires government employees to work in-person five days a week, hes had less luck pushing business leaders to mandate stricter in-office requirements.

Its time, he said last year. New York City cant run from home.

Existential Risk

Worker attendance at New York offices during the fourth quarter of 2022 recovered to about 43% of pre-pandemic levels on average, according to badge-tracking data from Kastle Systems. On Tuesdays, though, that jumps to an average 51% and plunges to 23% on Fridays.

Office attendance has ticked up when employers issue mandates for more in-person days, but theyre not a cure-all and a wide variability in company policies has left many pandemic-era habits in place. For example, Blackstone asked investment professionals to come into the office five days a week, but workday traffic at its headquarters at 345 Park Avenue remains half of its 2019 level. At American Express, which doesnt have in-office requirements, only 31% of pre-pandemic workday traffic is back at its headquarters at 200 Vesey Street.

At eight major Manhattan office buildings, foot traffic is down about 52% on Fridays and 45% on Mondays compared with pre-Covid, according to a Bloomberg News analysis of Placer.ai data.

Researchers have modeled a 40% drop in office market value as office towers sit partially empty, which they estimate would cost $5 billion in lost tax revenue, or 5% of the citys annual budget. New Yorks future sales tax revenue could also diminish as half-empty office buildings drive sluggish spending. It could also take a hit to its income tax base if employees continue to relocate elsewhere.

Thats a big hole that will need to be plugged with new taxes, lower spending, said Columbia University professor Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh, who referred to the situation in a recent panel as a potential urban doom loop.

The city is still seeing the impacts on its transit system, where weekday ridership has recovered only 64% on average in January and revenue shortfalls are expected to hit over $2 billion a year through 2026.

With pandemic aid running out, the agency is planning service cuts to about seven lines on Mondays and Fridays, including the 1 train that connects Manhattan and the Bronx, and the L and F trains, which run across Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan.

The change will be felt by working-class New Yorkers, who are back to work five or six days a week. They cant afford a $50 Uber, and arent able to work remotely, said MTA Chief Executive Officer Janno Lieber in November.

Forget about it

While New York has a history of overcoming economic shocks like the September 11 terrorist attacks and the 2008 financial crisis, business owners say they are struggling to adapt to the new three-day workweek.

Sams Falafel owner Emad Ahmed said foot traffic near Wall Street is the worst it's been in his 30 years of business. Only on a sunny midweek day do sales recover to about 60% of what they were, he said. Meanwhile, the rising cost of gas and ingredients have pressured his business.

Monday, Friday, forget about it, said Ahmed, 57, who parks his truck in Zuccotti Park and notches only 30% of his pre-Covid revenue on those days. You lose money when nobody is here.

Jordan Cohen, the manager of Bryant Park Grill in Midtown Manhattan, said about 40% fewer diners are now showing up on Mondays and Fridays for the power lunch hubs $22 chicken Caesar salad and $50 braised lamb shank.

To make up for the lost business, the restaurant has leaned on corporate events on slow weeknights and has clawed back around 90% of pre-pandemic revenue. But even those events get dinged by the hybrid workweek: At parties where employers invite 300 attendees, only about half will show up, Cohen said.

And Sweetgreen, a salad chain ubiquitous with New York Citys fleece-vest set, said the start and end of the week used to be its strongest sales days, but Mondays and Fridays are definitely not the same, said Sweetgreen co-founder and CEO Jonathan Neman, on a November earnings call.

On a Monday in October at a Bryant Park Sweetgreen known for lines stretching down the block on busy days, office workers in button-down shirts and high heels breezed in and out with $15 salads in hand.

That was surprisingly easy, a woman leaving the salad counter said to her companion.

Yeah, it doesnt feel like a madhouse in there, which is weird, he replied.

Bloomberg found the longest wait for a salad at the Bryant Park Sweetgreen at noon was around 13.5 minutes on a Wednesday. By contrast, it took only four minutes to breeze through the line on a Friday.

Sweetgreen is now renegotiating leases with landlords to structure rent as a percentage of sales, versus a fixed amount common with commercial rents.

With offices emptier on Mondays and Fridays, business travelers are cutting hotel stays short by a day or two and flying in just for midweek, said Vijay Dandapani, president and CEO of the Hotel Association of New York City.

Business travel has rebounded the most in places like Austin, Texas, and Charlotte, North Carolina, where workers are back in physical offices, according to hospitality data and analytics firm STR. In Austin, hotels recovered to 92% of pre-pandemic occupancy on Mondays of last year, while New York hotels were only around 83% recovered, and San Francisco was even further behind, at 74%.

Resistance to coming into the office at the end of the week runs so deep that when a large financial company rented out a Fitzpatrick Hotel Group bar in Midtown Manhattan on a Friday evening, only about a third of the 130 invited employees showed up, said John Fitzpatrick, who owns the company's two New York City hotels.

To lose that amount of business on a Friday, which is one of your busiest days, is huge, said Fitzpatrick, who depends on business travelers for 70% of his clientele.

To drum up business, hes considering raffling a free trip to Ireland to Friday bar customers. Another marketing idea is to encourage tourists to extend their New York City holidays by promoting the hotel as a remote-work haven on Fridays.

We have to come up with something, Fitzpatrick said.

More On Bloomberg

readabilityObject.excerpt: That translates into big savings for individuals, who are spending nearly $5,000 a year less on meals, shopping and entertainment near work as work schedules shift to a new norm.
